case_name: Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited v. Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh

facts.text: The appellant is Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited, a textile mill with factory situate at Jalgaon.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited, is a textile mill and its factory is situate at Jalgaon.

facts.text: The respondent is Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh, representing the employees of the appellant-Company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh, represents the employees of the appellant-Company.

facts.text: The respondent issued a notice to the appellant under s. 42(2) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, demanding reasonable bonus for January 1, 1955 to December 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent on behalf of the employees issued a notice to the appellant under s. 42 2  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, demanding payment of reasonable bonus for the period from January 1, 1955 to December 31, 1955.

facts.text: Negotiations regarding the bonus demand failed.

anchor.surface_text: Negotiations in this regard having failed,

facts.text: The respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946 for arbitration of the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the said Act for arbitration of the dispute arising out of the said notice.

facts.text: The Industrial Court, as arbitrator, followed the Full Bench Formula and ascertained surplus of Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting prior charges from gross profits.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator, i.e. the Industrial Court, following the Full Bench Formula, ascertained the surplus to be Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting the prior charges from the gross profits of the Company,

facts.text: The Industrial Court did not give any credit to the rehabilitation amount apart from the statutory depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: but it did not give any credit to the rehabilitation amount apart from the statutory depreciation.

facts.text: The Industrial Court estimated the amount required for rehabilitation at Rs. 60 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: It estimated the amount required for rehabilitation at Rs. 60 lakhs out of this amount it deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves

facts.text: The Industrial Court deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing reserves from the Rs. 60 lakhs rehabilitation amount.

anchor.surface_text: out of this amount it deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves and the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over a period of 15 years

facts.text: Balance of Rs. 9 lakhs for rehabilitation spread over 15 years gave Rs. 60,000 for the year in question.

anchor.surface_text: and the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over a period of 15 years gave the figure of Rs. 60,000 as the amount that should be set apart for the year in question for rehabilitation.

facts.text: Statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639.

anchor.surface_text: As the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, it came to the conclusion that the Company would not be entitled to any allocation as a prior charge for rehabilitation.

facts.text: The Industrial Court fixed surplus at Rs. 2.20 lakhs and awarded four months basic wages as bonus to employees.

anchor.surface_text: After excluding the said item of rehabilitation, it fixed the surplus in a sum of Rs. 2.20 lakhs and awarded to the employees four months basic wages as bonus.

facts.text: The Industrial Court assumed reserves were used as working capital but considered it immaterial as rehabilitation spending over 15 years by instalments.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that until some amount is required to be spent for rehabilitation, replacement or modernization, reserves must be used as working capital, but Shri Vimadalals argument overlooks that the amount required to be spent for rehabilitation over a course of 15 years is not required to be spent all at once, but by instalments over a long period.

facts.text: The Industrial Court did not record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital; it was only an assumption.

anchor.surface_text: These observations did not record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court,

facts.text: Appellant did not place any relevant and acceptable evidence before the Industrial Court to prove reserves were used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant could not succeed, unless it proved by relevant and acceptable evidence that the reserves were so utilised and that it did not place before the Industrial Court any such evidence to prove that fact.

facts.text: No specific allegation made by appellant in written-statement before Industrial Court that reserves were utilised as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: In the written-statement filed by the appellant before the Industrial Court, no specific allegation is made that the reserves were utilised as working capital,

facts.text: Respondent did not accept that reserve funds were utilised as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it must be held that the respondent did not accept the position that the reserve funds were utilised as working capital.

facts.text: General Superintendent of appellant-Company did not depose that reserves were used as working capital and did not prove balance-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance is placed upon the evidence of the General Superintendent of the appellant-Company, but a perusal of that evidence discloses that the said witness has not deposed that the Company used the reserves as working capital nor does the said witness seek to prove either the balance-sheet or any extract taken therefrom.

facts.text: Rs. 51 lakhs representing reserves were not used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from calculations in arriving at the surplus.

anchor.surface_text: As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

issues.text: what extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises the question as to what extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained. It would be enough if we narrated only the facts relevant to the question raised.

issues.text: what is the scope of the finding of the Industrial Court in this regard

anchor.surface_text: The first question, therefore, is, what is the scope of the finding of the Industrial Court in this regard ? The Industrial Court in dealing with the contentions of the parties before it observed as follows It is true that until some amount is required to be spent for rehabilitation, replacement or modernization, reserves must be used as working capital, but Shri Vimadalals argument overlooks that the amount required to be spent for rehabilitation over a course of 15 years is number required to be spent all at once, but by instalments over a long period.

issues.text: whether the mere availability of reserves or the simple earmarking for specific purposes would be sufficient to claim the said amounts as deductions

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the mere availability of reserves or the simple earmarking for specific purposes would be sufficient to claim the said amounts as deductions. We do number think that by using the said words this Court meant to depart from the well-recognized principle that if the general reserves have number been used as working capital, they cannot be deducted from the rehabilitation amount.

issues.text: What then is the procedure to be followed for ascertaining the said facts

anchor.surface_text: What then is the procedure to be followed for ascertaining the said facts ? The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

holdings.text: These observations did not record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court, as, in the view taken by it, it was immaterial whether the reserves were used as working capital or not.

anchor.surface_text: These observations did not record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court, as, in the view taken by it, it was immaterial whether the reserves were used as working capital or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual analysis of Industrial Court's observations shows no explicit finding, only assumption due to immateriality in its view.

holdings.text: We do not think that the aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the State of affairs in that year is the guiding factor.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the State of affairs in that year is the guiding factor. If in a subsequent year any part of the reserves used as working capital is released, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year and so on for subsequent years otherwise it will lead to the anomaly of the reserves being excluded from the amount required for rehabilitation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Opinion leads to anomaly inconsistent with prior decisions; surplus determined by annual state of affairs, future releases for future years.

holdings.text: We do not think that by using the said words this Court meant to depart from the well-recognized principle that if the general reserves have not been used as working capital, they cannot be deducted from the rehabilitation amount.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the mere availability of reserves or the simple earmarking for specific purposes would be sufficient to claim the said amounts as deductions. We do not think that by using the said words this Court meant to depart from the well-recognized principle that if the general reserves have not been used as working capital, they cannot be deducted from the rehabilitation amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets Associated Cement precedent; mere availability or simple earmarking insufficient without actual use as working capital.

holdings.text: The mere nominal allocation for binding purposes, such as gratuity etc., in the companys books is not enough. It must be ascertained by the Industrial Court on the material placed before it whether the said amount is far in excess of the requirements of the particular purpose for which it is so earmarked and whether it is only a device to reduce the claim of the labour for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The mere nominal allocation for binding purposes, such as gratuity etc., in the companys books is not enough. It must be ascertained by the Industrial Court on the material placed before it whether the said amount is far in excess of the requirements of the particular purpose for which it is so earmarked and whether it is only a device to reduce the claim of the labour for bonus. We do not suggest that it is the duty of the Industrial Court to ascertain the correct or exact figure required for a particular purpose but it is certainly its duty to discover whether the so called earmarking for a particular purpose is a device to circumvent the formula.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Earmarking must be reasonable and not a device; Industrial Court to scrutinize based on evidence.

holdings.text: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Employer bears burden as claimant; must use relevant acceptable evidence given importance of rehabilitation item.

holdings.text: But in the absence of an agreement, the procedure prescribed in Order XIX of the Code of Civil Procedure may usefully be followed by the tribunals so that both the parties may have full opportunity to establish their respective cases.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of holding an enquiry or a proceeding under the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, s. 118 of the said Act confers on the Industrial Court the same powers as are vested in Courts in respect of - a proof of facts by affidavits ... Order XIX of the Code of Civil Procedure empowers the Court to have particular facts-proved by affidavits. ... But in the absence of an agreement, the procedure prescribed in Order XIX of the Code of Civil Procedure may usefully be followed by the tribunals so that both the parties may have full opportunity to establish their respective cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: BIRA s.118 empowers like civil courts; CPC O.19 allows affidavits with cross-exam; equity demands opportunity, supported by precedents.

holdings.text: we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.

holdings.text: As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annual instalment for rehab Rs.60,000 less than statutory depreciation Rs.83,639; no additional prior charge.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.
ased, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year and so on for subsequent years otherwise it will lead t

edges.explanation: The holding rejects the Industrial Court's future-oriented view, emphasizing the state of affairs at year-end for determining working capital use, supporting the principle's focus on actual usage.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the State of affairs in that year is the guiding factor. If in a subsequent year any part of the reserves used as working capital is released, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year and so on for subsequent years otherwise it will lead to the anomaly of the reserves being excluded from the amount required for rehabilitation,

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

anchor.surface_text: or charge over the bonus shall be deducted to arrive at the surplus. No question of deducting any other amount reserved in regard to the profits of th

anchor.surface_text: her amount reserved in regard to the profits of that year arises. But the companypany has specifically earmarked certain amounts for specific binding

edges.explanation: Holding h3 on reserves principle directly addresses i3 on sufficiency of earmarking.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the mere availability of reserves or the simple earmarking for specific purposes would be sufficient to claim the said amounts as deductions. We do not think that by using the said words this Court meant to depart from the well-recognized principle that if the general reserves have not been used as working capital, they cannot be deducted from the rehabilitation amount.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.
y are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specifie purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and accepta

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that mere nominal allocation is insufficient constrains application of prior charges concept c10 to genuine ascertained amounts
Holding requiring Industrial Court to ascertain beyond mere allocation supports Full Bench Formula application at c8.

anchor.surface_text: The mere nominal allocation for binding purposes, such as gratuity etc., in the companys books is not enough. It must be ascertained by the Industrial Court on the material placed before it whether the said amount is far in excess of the requirements of the particular purpose for which it is so earmarked and whether it is only a device to reduce the claim of the labour for bonus. We do not suggest that it is the duty of the Industrial Court to ascertain the correct or exact figure required for a particular purpose but it is certainly its duty to discover whether the so called earmarking for a particular purpose is a device to circumvent the formula.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

anchor.surface_text: an enquiry or a proceeding under the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, s. 118 of the said Act companyfers on the Industrial Court the same power

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of holding an enquiry or a proceeding under the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, s. 118 of the said Act confers on the Industrial Court the same powers as are vested in Courts in respect of - a proof of facts by affidavits ... Order XIX of the Code of Civil Procedure empowers the Court to have particular facts-proved by affidavits. ... But in the absence of an agreement, the procedure prescribed in Order XIX of the Code of Civil Procedure may usefully be followed by the tribunals so that both the parties may have full opportunity to establish their respective cases.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.
